STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 5, 2025
Trisha Sverns
WEST MI PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN
PO BOX 232,
DORR, MI, 49323-0232
Re: License #: CB410381414
Dear Trisha Sverns:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
April 30, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CWCC Contract: Attachment I
(2) Outcomes to be measured
a. Safety Goals
iii. Service plan approval
At least 95% of children supervised by the Service Provider shall have a case service
plan approved within 14 days of caseworker submission to the supervisor for review.
The agency was found to be at 90% which is down slightly from 92% last year.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/25/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/3/2024
5/30/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/7/2023
CWCC Contract: Attachment I
(2) Outcomes to be measured
a. Safety Goals
ii. Initial Service Plan Timely Completion
At least 95% of children supervised by the Grantee shall have an initial service plan
completed within 30 days of entry into foster care and quarterly thereafter in
accordance with the guidelines in FOM.
T he agency was found to be at 91% which is down from 96% last year.
2

CWCC Contract: Attachment I
(2) Outcomes to be measured
b. Permanency Goals
i. Worker-Parent Visit
At least 85% of parents whose children have a permanency goal of reunification and
are supervised by the Grantee, shall have face-to- face contact by the assigned
caseworker in accordance with the guidelines in FOM.
The agency was found to be at 75% which is down slightly from 77% last year.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/25/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/3/2024
CWCC Contract: Attachment I
(2) Outcomes to be measured
b. Permanency Goals
ii. Parent-Child Visit
No fewer than 85% of required visits between parent and child should occur in
accordance with FOM.
The agency was found to be at 70% which is the same as last year.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/25/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/3/2024
CWCC Contract: Attachment I
(2) Outcomes to be measured
b. Permanency Goals
iii. Return Home Visit
The caseworker must complete 95% of required visits with families after children
have returned to the parental home.
The agency was found to be at 87% which is the down from 96% year.
3

CWCC Contract: Attachment I
(2) Outcomes to be measured
c. Well-being Goals
ii. Medical-Periodic (Well Child/Yearly)
Following an initial medical examination, at least 95% of children supervised by the
Grantee shall receive periodic and ongoing medical examinations and screenings
according to the guidelines set forth by the American Academy of Pediatrics.
The agency was found to be at 86% which is an increase from 81% last year.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/25/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/3/2024
5/30/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/7/2023
CWCC Contract: Attachment I
(2) Outcomes to be measured
c. Well-being Goals
iii. Dental-Initial
At least 90% of children shall have an initial dental examination within 90 days of the
child's entry into care unless the child is less than one year of age or had a dental
exam within three months prior to entry into care.
The agency was found to be at 87% which is the same as last year.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/25/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/3/2024
5/30/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/7/2023
CWCC Contract: Attachment I
(2) Outcomes to be measured
c. Well-being Goals
iv. Dental-Yearly
At least 95% of children shall have an annual dental examination
The agency was found to be at 73% which is down from 81% last year.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/25/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/3/2024
5/30/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/7/2023
4

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• All employee references must be dated and include the name of reference
obtained.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency renewal inspection was completed on 4/1/24 and the CAP was
approved on 5/3/24. The agency was cited for 7 violations, 6 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 6, there was an improvement in individual incidents of
non-compliance within 1 of the violation areas, a slight increase in number of
individual incidents in 3 areas and 2 areas remained the same. In 2023, 8
violations were established, 4 of which were repeated this year. All of the repeated
violations remain close to the same number of individual incidents of non-
compliances. The agency will need to establish additional corrective planning for
the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the previous year’s CAP has been somewhat effective. Citations related
to personnel files were addressed by adding a reminder in the onboarding
checklist. The KPI's have been more difficult to address due to ongoing issues
with turnover at the partner agencies.
The chief administrator indicated turnover at the agencies has been a primary
barrier, especially at the worker and supervisor level. However, workforce
development grants issues by WMPC did show some positive impact on turnover.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff, one via telephone and one via video
conference. Staff reported feeling supported by the agency. Supervisors and
coworkers are available as needed to assist. Staff did not report any concerns
related to the agency.
5

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency does not have a physical location so a walk through was not
completed. A variance was granted on 12/13/2022 to not have a physical office
space as workers were remote. The variance is due to expire on 12/31/2025.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
N/A
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
___________5/1/2025___________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
